Award.AwardTitle: 2015 Rocky Mountain-Great Plains Graduate Research Workshop in Combinatorics
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Second Rocky Mountain-Great Plains Graduate Research Workshop in Combinatorics (GRWC), which will be held in Ames, IA during June 1-12, 2015, will involve approximately 35 graduate students, 6 postdoctoral researchers, and more than a dozen faculty members in an intense two-week collaborative research experience. Participants will work to solve important, relevant problems from graph theory, enumeration, combinatorial matrix theory, finite geometry, and other modern sub-disciplines of combinatorics. Students will prepare open problems prior to the workshop under the guidance of faculty mentors from the organizing committee, which consists of faculty from Iowa State University, the University of Colorado Denver, the University of Denver, the University of Nebraska Lincoln, and the University of Wyoming. These problems, presented at the workshop by their proposers or hosted on the workshop's secure problem wiki, will be worked on by small groups of participating students, postdocs, and faculty. For more information about the GRWC, including a detailed description of the workshop format, please see the workshop website at http://sites.google.com/site/rmgpgrwc

The goal of the collaborations at the heart of the GRWC is to produce high-quality, publishable research on a variety of topics. Another longer-term goal of the workshop is to help student participants expand their professional research networks. A strong research network is often a crucial part of building a generative and sustainable research program, and establishing these connections at an early career stage can have a long-term positive effect on the quality, impact, and depth of a professional's research portfolio. Participation in the GRWC will allow students to cultivate a large professional network of peers from the combinatorics community with whom they will be able to interact and collaborate throughout their careers. The GRWC will also offer professional development workshops to help students and postdocs prepare for job searches and future careers in academia, industry, or government. This award supports students and postdoctoral researchers only; faculty support is provided by the organizing institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2015 Rocky Mountain-Great Plains Graduate Research Workshop in Combinatorics (henceforth called GRWC) was held from May 31 – June 13th at Iowa State University in Ames, IA and co-organized with the University of Colorado Denver, the University of Denver, the University of Nebraska-Lincoln and the University of Wyoming. GRWC 2015 brought together 39 graduate students, 7 postdoctoral associates, and 12 faculty from 15 different institutions for a two-week intensive collaborative research experience. In addition to conducting research on open combinatorics problems, participants took part in professional development sessions and a number of planned activities that allowed them to network with both their peers and participating faculty.  The participants in GRWC given 20 presentations about their GRWC research.  Two research papers have appeared and four more are under review.

GRWC 2015 was the second in a series of annual summer workshops and continuation activities that began in 2014 These workshops are aimed at graduate students and postdoctoral associates in combinatorics and related fields. GRWC was conceived in part as a response to emerging challenges and modern career realities for mathematics PhDs.   The increasing complexity and interdisciplinary nature of important problems in mathematics and its applications now frequently require collaboration of researchers with different backgrounds.  Due to the explosive growth of new opportunities in industry and government, the academic job market's stagnant growth, and increasing interest among students in nonacademic opportunities, more new mathematics PhDs  are taking nonacademic positions.  In addition, an increasingly diverse group of institutions, including small liberal arts schools, are expecting their faculty members to maintain active research programs. Limited time and lack of local collaborators present challenges to these faculty.  Experience in research teams and a strong network of collaborators can help such faculty maintain their research programs.   Thus there are needs for more significant exposure to collaborative research environments, opportunities to build collaboration networks, and better professional development activities focused on industrial and government opportunities as part of graduate student training. 

GRWC uses student-posed problems, which are presented during the first week.  Faculty mentors help students cultivate good problems and develop brief written descriptions as part of the pre-workshop professional development.  The research in GRWC is done in collaborative research groups, which are formed in the first week and do much of their work in the second. During the second week, in addition to research, various professional development activities also take place.  Research on the problems continues after the workshop, with some groups holding small additional research gatherings in order to complete the project.

Participants reported a very positive experience at GRWC 2015: 100% would recommend GRWC to others. One student said, “This has been the most influential workshop of my graduate career thus far! The friendships, knowledge, and times shared will allow me to become a better mathematician.”
